Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research: Complex Interactions in the Content Distribution Ecosystem

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Internet services such as web search (e.g, Google and Bing), social networks (e.g., Facebook), and online video streaming (e.g., Netflix and YouTube) are now an important human activity. Underlying such services is a vast, and increasingly complex system of servers, networks, and software controlled by a variety of entities such as content providers (CPs) who own or generate the content, content distribution networks (CDNs) who distribute that content to users, and Internet Service Providers (ISPs) who own and operate the underlying network infrastructure. These entities form the content distribution ecosystem, each with its own business interest, each attempting to optimize its own cost and performance, more often individually, but sometimes in cooperation with others. This project is focused on understanding the complex interactions among these different entities with the view of providing better architectural solutions to facilitate those interactions. Insights gained from the project can help guide the evolution of future Internet services, resulting in better quality-of-experience (QoE) for the users and greater system efficiencies for the entities in the ecosystem.

This project advances a framework to study complex interactions in the content distribution ecosystem from multiple perspectives -- control information, decision points, time scales and local vs. global decision making, and applies this framework to understand their roles and effects on user QoE. The project is organized along four main threads: 1) Complex interactions between CDNs and ISPs: Characterize effects of CDN actions such as content adaptation and request routing on ISP actions such as traffic engineering and traffic shaping; 2) Complex interactions between CPs and CDNs: Characterize CP actions such as choosing the right CDN to deliver their content with CDN actions such as server selection; 3) Complex interactions between (uni- and multi-path) TCP and applications: Characterize interactions between control loops present in applications such as video streaming and protocols such as (MP)TCP; 4) Measurement, trace-driven evaluation, and controlled and "in the wild" experimentation. All four threads are connected by an analytical thrust focused on the development of theoretical models, advanced algorithms, and performance bounds based on optimization, control and economic methods.

The main premise behind this project is that content distribution is becoming more complex with increasing numbers of entities and varied interactions between them. This complexity requires new analytical and algorithmic methods to model, understand, control, and optimize content distribution. The project takes a first step towards developing these tools and methods, and applying them to interactions that arise between CPs, CDNs, and ISPs, and between different application-level and transport level data transfers. If successful, the project will produce sound theoretical underpinnings and provide general design guidelines in effectively improving the system performance and enhancing overall user QoE and benefit CPs, CDNs and ISPs alike.

The successful completion of this project promises to enhance the economic viability of the content distribution ecosystem and the Internet infrastructure at large. Moreover, it will lead to a better understanding of how to engineer large systems consisting of a multitude of diverse interacting components. Educational activities for this project will enhance undergraduate, graduate, and professional education lying at the intersection of networking, modeling, control theory, and complex systems. The PIs will accomplish these goals through 1) creation of courses and course material on complex systems, content distribution systems, and mathematics of interacting systems appropriate for seniors and graduate students; 2) development of outreach activities aimed at increasing participation of undergraduate women and minority students in research as well as engagement with the broader networking community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since their advent in the early 90s, web applications and services have evolved from the simple client server model, to a vast and complex system consisting of numerous, network elements, and software components owned and controlled by a variety of entities such as content providers (CPs), content distribution networks (CDNs), and Internet Service Providers (ISPs). The content distribution ecosystem is a complex system consisting of tens of thousands of major independent entities interacting with each other in complicated ways. Providing a high quality of experience (QoE) for their users is the key goal for any content provider (CP). Understanding and optimizing QoE requires a fundamental understanding of the complex interactions that underlie the content distribution ecosystem.

The overall goal of our research is to study complex interactions from the critical need to understand and optimize them. To this end, we have developed theoretical models, advanced algorithms and performance bounds based on optimization, control and game-theoretic methods. We have not only studied technical solutions for better coordination of the entities, system components, and protocols, but also the broader picture that relates to the incentive structure of the content distribution ecosystem The key outcomes of our project include the following:

i) Modeling, Analysis, and Optimization of Caches in Networks: we have made several novel advances and contributions in these fronts. This includes a generalization of the so-called “characteristic time” (CT) approximation of a cache system to handle general request processes.  We have applied the above CT approximation to cache optimization where a large cache is shared by multiple content providers, each using a “least recent used” replacement policy.  We have also devised self-tuning size-aware policies to manage memory-resident hot object caches in a CDN server and showed that our approach results in a higher HOC hit rate than the current state-of-the-art. As modern CDNs use hierarchies of caches to store content, we developed analytical models that can be applied to arbitrary cache hierarchies described by directed acyclic graphs. Our model predicts hit rates and other metrics for upper-layer caches within a hierarchy significantly better than prior state-of-the-art. We also used this model to shed light on fundamental questions of cache hierarchy design, such as how to size individual caches and how to store and route content in a cache hierarchy.

ii) Cache provisioning in global CDNs.  We introducedthe notion of a footprint descriptor -- a succinct space-time representation of the cache requirements of a traffic class and developed a footprint descriptor calculus that allows us to predict cache performance when different traffic classes are added, subtracted and/or scaled. We show that the calculus predicts cache performance with high.  Importantly, our footprint descriptor work is currently being used in production to provide a provisioning service for CDN operators at Akamai.

iii) Video bit rate adaptation. We devised three algorithms and implemented them in production. Two algorithms adaptively set the bitrate of the video to maximize video quality and minimize re-buffering. The third algorithm opportunistically replaces low-quality video segments in the video player's buffer with higher quality ones, before they can be rendered to the user, allowing the video player to react more quickly to network connectivity improvements. Notably, all three algorithms are now part of the MPEG-DASH video player reference standard. Consequently our algorithms are now successfully deployed in production in the field by major video providers, including BBC, CBS, Orange, and likely many others who use the reference standard and its algorithms.

iv) Making Content Caching Policies ‘Smart’ using the DeepCache Framework: We developed a novel deep learning framework, DeepCache, for content caching, which can significantly boost cache performance. It comprises of two main components: i) Object Characteristics Predictor, and ii) a Caching Policy Component. Extensive experiments show that applying DeepCache Framework to existing cache policies, significantly increases the number of cache hits. We have developed an open-source platform that incorporates Deep Cache and various other policies, with publicly available datasets and machine learning models.

Our research outcomes have provided the scientific underpinnings on how such an evolution could happen by modeling and analyzing mechanisms for coordinating different entities, software.  Several of our research papers have received “Best Paper” awards or other awards. The algorithms and mechanisms have also been adopted by content service industry, e.g., the MPEG-DASH industry forum (DASHIF).  Our research project has also provided both undergraduate and graduate students with hands-on experiences in CDN system designs and development. In particular, several women and under-represented minority students have participated in our research project. We have also fostered closer interactions between the research community and the content services industry.
